titlestmt.titleproper: Still, Valerie Artifacts and Papers, 1970s-2021, undated
Guide to the Valerie Still Artifacts and Papers, 1970s-2021, undated 2020ua043
titlestmt.author: Ruth E. Bryan, Marie Dale, Emily B. Collier

publicationstmt.publisher: University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-03-31 12:39:26 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

change.item: Added minimal description for addition 2021ua034. Date range changed from 1970s-2020, undated, to 1970s-2021, undated. Extent changed from 6 cubic feet (2 document boxes, 4 record storage cartons, one oversize box, one tube, and one framed item) to 9 cubic feet (6 record storage cartons, 2 document boxes, one oversize box, two map folders, one tube, and one framed item). Finding aid date changed from 2024 February 28 to 2024 October 24. Edition changed to 2nd edition. Scope and contents note updated to include information from the addition. Subjects added for scrapbooks, photograph albums, photographs, video tapes, motion pictures, electronic records, and African American women basketball players. Agents added for University of Kentucky Lady Kats and University of Kentucky basketball history.

repository.corpname: University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center

did.unittitle: Valerie Still Artifacts and Papers

physdesc.extent: 6 record storage cartons, 2 document boxes, one oversize box, two map folders, one tube, and one framed item

did.abstract: The Valerie Still Artifacts and Papers (dated 1970s-2021, undated; 9 cubic feet, 6 record storage cartons, 2 document boxes, one oversize box, two map folders, one tube, and one framed item) comprise correspondence; scrapbooks, photograph albums, and photographs; books and a manuscript; game statistics, programs, and media guides; film and videocassette tapes; 23 artifacts (3 basketballs, 3 cups, 5 medals, 3 trophies, 1 shirt, 1 sweatshirt, 1 framed jersey, 5 plaques, 2 silver bowl, and one briefcase); honors and awards; eight framed posters, clippings, and photographs; 7 rolled posters and banner; one vinyl record; one coffee bag; and two pieces of jewelry (including the 1982 Southeastern Conference (SEC) championship ring, 2020) documenting Valerie Still's basketball career at the University of Kentucky and the American Basketball League, her basketball honors and awards, her writing and philanthropic work after college, and the 1981-1982 UK women's basketball team reunion and Southeastern Conference ring ceremony organized by Still at the UK King Alumni House, October 9, 2020.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to researchers by appointment

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged by format into four series: Papers, Artifacts, Books, and Addition 2021ua034

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Valerie Still, basketball player and coach, musician, historian, author, educator, consultant, and philanthropist, was born in Camden, New Jersey, on May 14, 1961. Her family included her father and mother, James Fleming Still (1922-1995) and Gwendolyn Ricketts Still (1931-2010), and nine brothers and sisters including former professional football player Art Barry Still (1955- ). After playing basketball at Cherry Hill High School East in Cherry Hill, New Jersey, she enrolled at the University of Kentucky in 1979, joining the basketball team from 1979-1983 and becoming the highest scoring basketball player, male or female, in the history of University of Kentucky basketball with 2,763 points and 1,525 rebounds. After leaving school to play professionally in Italy, she returned to the University of Kentucky and recieved her Bachelor of Science in Animal Science/Pre-Veterinary Medicine in 2000. She received a Master of Arts degree in African American Studies in 2007 followed by a doctorate in Sports Humanities at The Ohio State University. Professionally, she played in Italy for 12 years, winning an Italian Professional Basketball Championship. Still became one of the most popular and dominant players in the league, with numerous all-star appearances and scoring titles. She returned to the United States in 1996 and received two championships with Columbus Quest for the American Basketball League (ABL). After the ABL closed, she joined the Washington Mystics in the Woman's National Basketball Association (WNBA). After retiring from playing, she was an assistant coach in the WNBA with the Mystics and later with the Orlando Miracle.

Still is founder of the Valerie Still Foundation and the socially-conscious coffee company STILL Java. She is also a published author and co-owner of STILL Publications and is co-founder president of the Dr. Clarence B. Jones Institute for Social Advocacy. She has served as a newspaper columnist, host of various television shows, participant on a reality television show, and a live and recording musician. A youth series based on her family history, Still Alive on the Underground Railroad: Recollections of an American Family, was released in 2012 and 2013. Still published two memoirs, Playing Black and Blue: Still I Rise (STILL Productions) and Still Family: An Historic American Family Memoir (University Press of Kentucky) in 2018 and 2025, respectively. From 2024-2025, she served on the Executive Planning Committee for the Lexington (Kentucky) Freedom Train Project, raising funds to erect a monument to abolitionists Lewis and Harriet Hayden. Still has also established the University of Kentucky Athletics: Women's Basketball Oral History Project at the Louie B. Nunn Center for Oral History in the University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

Still has received many honors and awards, including induction into the Kentucky Sports Hall of Fame (1996), the University of Kentucky Athletic Hall of Fame (the only woman in the inaugural class, 2005), Camden County Sports Fall of Fame (2018), Woman's Basketball Hall of Fame (Class of 2019), the University of Kentucky Hall of Distinguished Alumni (2020, inducted 2021), the Philadelphia Sports Hall of Fame (2023), and University of Kentucky College of Agriculture, Food and Environment Distinguisehd Alumni (2024). In 2018, she received the New Jersey State Governor's Jefferson Award for her volunteer/public service work.

Still's ancestors include abolitionist William Still (known as the father of the Underground Railroad) and Dr. James Still (Still's great-great grandfather and William's older brother), who became a successful 19th-century physician. In 2005, Still campaigned for and petitioned the State of New Jersey to preserve Dr. James Still's medical office in Medford, New Jersey. In 2006, it became the first and only state-owned African American historic site in New Jersey. Still has a son, Aaron, with her former husband, Rob Lock. They were married from 1995-2007.
Sources: 1. Hall of Distinguished Alumni: Valerie Still, University of Kentucky Alumni Association. https://www.ukalumni.net/s/article/Valerie-Still. Accessed 2/28/2024.
2. Valerie Still, 2018 Sports Hall of Fame, NJSports.com. https://www.njsportsheroes.com/valeriestillbk.html. Accessed 2/28/2024.
3. Valerie Still, 2018 Sports Hall of Fame, CamdenCounty.com. https://www.camdencounty.com/valerie-still-2018-sports-hall-of-fame/. Accessed 2/28/2024.
4. Leadership Team, Clarence B. Jones Institute for Social Advocacy. https://www.drclarencebjonesinstitute.org/about-us/leadership-team/. Accessed 2/28/2024.
6. Dr. James Still Office Historic Site Overview, New Jersey State Park Service. https://nj.gov/dep/parksandforests/historic/drjamesstill.html. Accessed 2/28/2024.
7. Still, Valerie. Playing Black and Blue: Still I Rise. Still Publications, 2018.
8. Still, Valerie. Email to Ruth E. Bryan, 10/25/2024.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: 2020ua043 : [identification of item], Valerie Still Artifacts and Papers, 1970s-2021, undated, University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Valerie Still Artifacts and Papers (dated 1970s-2021, undated; 9 cubic feet, 6 record storage cartons, 2 document boxes, one oversize box, two map folders, one tube, and one framed item) comprise correspondence; scrapbooks, photograph albums, and photographs; books and a manuscript; game statistics, programs, and media guides; film and videocassette tapes; 23 artifacts (3 basketballs, 3 cups, 5 medals, 3 trophies, 1 shirt, 1 sweatshirt, 1 framed jersey, 5 plaques, 2 silver bowl, and one briefcase); honors and awards; eight framed posters, clippings, and photographs; 7 rolled posters and banner; one vinyl record; one coffee bag; and two pieces of jewelry (including the 1982 Southeastern Conference (SEC) championship ring, 2020) documenting Valerie Still's basketball career at the University of Kentucky and the American Basketball League, her basketball honors and awards, her writing and philanthropic work after college, and the 1981-1982 UK women's basketball team reunion and Southeastern Conference ring ceremony organized by Still at the UK King Alumni House, October 9, 2020.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the University of Kentucky. The University of Kentucky holds the copyright for materials created in the course of business by University of Kentucky employees. Copyright for all other materials has not been assigned to the University of Kentucky. For information about permission to reproduce or publish, please contact the Special Collections Research Center.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: 2020ua022 : 1982 UK Lady Kats SEC Champions Facebook group page, 2020 Feb 26-December 31 and 2022 February 4, University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.
